newsitem.title: USA: U.S. would consider new North Korea food appeal.
newsitem.headline: U.S. would consider new North Korea food appeal.

text.p: The United States said on Monday it would look favourably on another World Food Programme request for North Korea food aid, but another appeal was not expected soon.

State Department spokesman James Rubin said the U.N. agency is "somewhat oversubscribed" from its last appeal but "if there was such an appeal, we would take a good, hard look at it. And we have a very good record in this regard."

He spoke after North Korea complained through its official media that the U.S. position at a meeting in New York last week was that food aid can be expanded only after four-nation peace talks are launched.
Pyongyang accused Washington of using food as a political weapon.
The U.S. position is that it does not make humanitarian food aid conditional on the political issue of peace talks and Rubin reiterated that view on Monday.

But officials have long said privately that while the United States has and will respond to limited food aid appeals, any major effort to deal with North Korea's food shortages -- like providing fertilisers and related items -- would have to be discussed within the context of peace talks.
The United States has become a major donor to North Korea, providing $52 million in food aid through the World Food Programme in 1997 and a total of $60.4 million since 1995.
North Korea, according to experts, is suffering a famine due to shortages caused by several years of flooding and now a drought.

Pyongyang's negotiators have repeatedly raised the Stalinist regime's food needs during prepatory discussions related to U.S. and South Korean efforts to launch peace talks also involving North Korea and China.
The aim is to replace the fraying armistice that ended the 1950-53 Korean War with a permanent peace arrangement.
Prepatory talks to settle procedural issues related to formal peace talks were held in New York last week but ended without final agreement. They are to resume on Sept. 15.
North Korea on Sunday called the New York talks disappointing.

It said through a spokesman that peace talks should not cover the internal affairs of North Korea, but issues which include a peace agreement between the United States and North Korea and the withdrawal of U.S. troops from the Korean peninsula.

On Friday, the United States said a "significant" disagreement was over whether the peace talks agenda should be specific or general, and said it does not want to negotiate a U.S. withdrawal of troops from the Korean peninsula.
Contrary to Pyongyang's view, Rubin said the United States was "quite pleased with what happened in New York last week."

Elaborating on the agenda row, he said Washington wants the talks "to be about stability, about security, about confidence-building measures (and) are prepared to talk about the reasons why we have deployed so many American soldiers to defend our South Korean allies."

But if proposals that are "clearly non-starters" -- like withdrawal of U.S. forces -- are included in the agenda "we are just going to create a prescription for the talks bogging down later," he said.
Rubin expresed hope that North Korean negotiators will get new instructions from Pyongyang that will resolve the impasse.
